elements.content: A new 3D AgI-based coordination network, [Ag2(pz)­(bdc)·H2O] n (1; pz = pyrazine and H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid), was constructed by one-pot assembly and structurally established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction at different temperatures. Upon cooling from 298 to 93 K, 1 undergo an interesting single-crystal to single-crystal phase transition from orthorhombic Ibca (Z = 16) to Pccn (Z = 32) at around 148 K. Both phases show a rare 2-fold-interpenetrated 4-connected lvt network but incorporate different [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric secondary building units. It is worth mentioning that complex 1 shows red- and blue-shifted luminescences in the 290–170 and 140–80 K temperature ranges, respectively. The variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies suggest that the argentophilic interactions and rigidity of the structure dominated the luminescence chromism trends at the respective temperature ranges. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits a slight mechanoluminescence red shift from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K.
elements.clean_text: A new 3D AgI-based coordination network, [Ag2(pz)(bdc)⋅H2O] n  (1; pz = pyrazine and H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid), was constructed by one-pot assembly and structurally established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction at different temperatures. Upon cooling from 298 to 93 K, 1 undergo an interesting single-crystal to single-crystal phase transition from orthorhombic Ibca (Z = 16) to Pccn (Z = 32) at around 148 K. Both phases show a rare 2-fold-interpenetrated 4-connected lvt network but incorporate different [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric secondary building units. It is worth mentioning that complex 1 shows red- and blue-shifted luminescences in the 290-170 and 140-80 K temperature ranges, respectively. The variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies suggest that the argentophilic interactions and rigidity of the structure dominated the luminescence chromism trends at the respective temperature ranges. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits a slight mechanoluminescence red shift from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K.

elements.content:
A thermochromic luminescent 3D metal−organic framework exhibits interesting temperature-induced single-crystal to single-crystal phase transitions and segmented thermochromic luminescence.

Introduction

Emission materials that change their emissive behaviors along with various external stimuli were a fanatical pursuit for many years because of their potential application as smart materials for mechanical sensors, molecular fluorescent thermometers, luminescent switches, and informational displays. To realize luminescence chromism, flexibility is a key factor in these kinds of materials; that is to say, structures should be responsively changed based on the exerted stimuli. These changes in structures usually included lattice distortion, molecular conformational twisting or folding, variations in the metallophilicity, hydrogen-bonding or other supramolecular interactions, and guest component inclusion or exclusion. Many organic molecules, including organic dyes, liquid crystals, and polymers, have been proven to modulate their emission features in response to mechanical stimuli. Some coordination compounds with metallophilicity, such as a copper iodide cluster, showed varied emission colors depending on the temperature. Up to now, a number of two-coordinated AuI or four-coordinated PtII systems have been reported as vapor-responsive luminescent compounds or mechanoluminescent materials. Relevant studies on AgI compounds, however, are much less explored, and those materials with multi-stimuli-responsive characteristics are also rare. It also should be noted that AgI, with a d10 closed-shell electronic configuration, could show diverse coordinative geometries, which could thus bring some flexibility around the metal center; moreover, argentophilic interaction has a significant influence in the luminescent behaviors. So, AgI compounds will be a promising family as stimuli-responsive emission materials.
elements.clean_text:
A thermochromic luminescent 3D metal-organic framework exhibits interesting temperature-induced single-crystal to single-crystal phase transitions and segmented thermochromic luminescence.

Introduction

Emission materials that change their emissive behaviors along with various external stimuli were a fanatical pursuit for many years because of their potential application as smart materials for mechanical sensors, molecular fluorescent thermometers, luminescent switches, and informational displays. To realize luminescence chromism, flexibility is a key factor in these kinds of materials; that is to say, structures should be responsively changed based on the exerted stimuli. These changes in structures usually included lattice distortion, molecular conformational twisting or folding, variations in the metallophilicity, hydrogen-bonding or other supramolecular interactions, and guest component inclusion or exclusion. Many organic molecules, including organic dyes, liquid crystals, and polymers, have been proven to modulate their emission features in response to mechanical stimuli. Some coordination compounds with metallophilicity, such as a copper iodide cluster, showed varied emission colors depending on the temperature. Up to now, a number of two-coordinated AuI or four-coordinated PtII systems have been reported as vapor-responsive luminescent compounds or mechanoluminescent materials. Relevant studies on AgI compounds, however, are much less explored, and those materials with multi-stimuli-responsive characteristics are also rare. It also should be noted that AgI, with a d10 closed-shell electronic configuration, could show diverse coordinative geometries, which could thus bring some flexibility around the metal center; moreover, argentophilic interaction has a significant influence in the luminescent behaviors. So, AgI compounds will be a promising family as stimuli-responsive emission materials.

elements.content: During the course of our studies on stimuli-responsive luminescent hybrid materials based on coin–metal coordination clusters or polymers, we have discovered some temperature-dependent luminescence behaviors, mainly arising from temperature-dependent metallophilicity variations. Inspired by the successes of our previous work, we aimed to combine mechanical and thermal stimuli into one functional coordination network and hoped to obtain dual-stimuli-responsive emissions.
elements.clean_text: During the course of our studies on stimuli-responsive luminescent hybrid materials based on coin-metal coordination clusters or polymers, we have discovered some temperature-dependent luminescence behaviors, mainly arising from temperature-dependent metallophilicity variations. Inspired by the successes of our previous work, we aimed to combine mechanical and thermal stimuli into one functional coordination network and hoped to obtain dual-stimuli-responsive emissions.

elements.content: On the basis of the above consideration, herein, we present a AgI-based coordination network, [Ag2(pz)­(bdc)·H2O] n (1; pz = pyrazine and H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid), which has a 3D 2-fold-interpenetrated lvt network based on [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric secondary binding units (SBUs) and incorporates a 1D helical water chain in the void along the a axis. Upon cooling to around 147 K, the space-group symmetry of 1 changes from Ibca to Pccn. The topologies of the coordination network and hydrogen-bonded 1D water chain remain almost the same, but partial [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBUs become different. Interestingly, compound 1 shows segmented thermochromic luminescence: red- and blue-shifted emissions in the 290–170 and 140–80 K temperature ranges, respectively, which are correlated to not only variation of the intramolecular Ag···Ag contacts but also the phase transitions of single crystals when the temperature is varied. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits moderate mechanoluminescence red shifts from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K. The correlations between luminescence chromism phenomena and external stimuli are well illustrated by the variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above consideration, herein, we present a AgI-based coordination network, [Ag2(pz)(bdc)⋅H2O] n  (1; pz = pyrazine and H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid), which has a 3D 2-fold-interpenetrated lvt network based on [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric secondary binding units (SBUs) and incorporates a 1D helical water chain in the void along the a axis. Upon cooling to around 147 K, the space-group symmetry of 1 changes from Ibca to Pccn. The topologies of the coordination network and hydrogen-bonded 1D water chain remain almost the same, but partial [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBUs become different. Interestingly, compound 1 shows segmented thermochromic luminescence: red- and blue-shifted emissions in the 290-170 and 140-80 K temperature ranges, respectively, which are correlated to not only variation of the intramolecular Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts but also the phase transitions of single crystals when the temperature is varied. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits moderate mechanoluminescence red shifts from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K. The correlations between luminescence chromism phenomena and external stimuli are well illustrated by the variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies.

elements.content: Solution assembly of Ag2O, pz, and H2bdc in 1:1 (v/v) water–methanol mixed with 400 μL of ammonia at room temperature yielded colorless, very long (up to several centimeters) rod crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 is supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is well-matched with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The dissimilarity in the intensity is possibly caused by the preferred orientation of the powder samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 is performed under a N2 environment (Figure S2). For 1, the first weight loss of 3.02% from 30 to 80 °C is attributed to the extraction of water molecules (calcd 3.77%); then a platform appears in 80–135 °C, and the dehydrated network decomposes from 135 °C by removal of the organic ligands. These results match well with structural information on 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solution assembly of Ag2O, pz, and H2bdc in 1:1 (v/v) water-methanol mixed with 400 μL of ammonia at room temperature yielded colorless, very long (up to several centimeters) rod crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 is supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is well-matched with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The dissimilarity in the intensity is possibly caused by the preferred orientation of the powder samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 is performed under a N2 environment (Figure S2). For 1, the first weight loss of 3.02% from 30 to 80 °C is attributed to the extraction of water molecules (calcd 3.77%); then a platform appears in 80-135 °C, and the dehydrated network decomposes from 135 °C by removal of the organic ligands. These results match well with structural information on 1.

elements.content: SCXRD analysis demonstrates that 1@298 K is a 3D class IIa, doubly interpenetrated lvt network. It crystallizes in the orthorhombic Ibca space group at 298 K. The asymmetric unit of 1@298 K consists of two crystallographically unique AgI atoms, one pz ligand, one bdc2– dianion, and one solvent water molecule. As depicted in a, the Ag1 atom locates in a T-shaped geometry, coordinated by two O atoms from two different bdc2– ligands and one N atom of the pz ligand [Ag1–O1 = 2.172(4) Å, Ag1–O2i = 2.193(3) Å, and Ag1–N1 = 2.365(4) Å; ∠O1–Ag1–O2i = 164.25(14)°]. Differently, Ag2 is in a three-coordinated Y-shaped geometry comprised of two O atoms of different bdc2– ligands and one N atom belonging to the pz ligand [Ag2–O4 = 2.296(4) Å, Ag2–O3iii = 2.245(4) Å, and Ag2–N2iv = 2.302(4) Å; ∠O3–Ag2–O4 = 139.16(15)°]. Both the Ag–O and Ag–N bond lengths fall in the normal ranges observed in related complexes. Notably, the separations between the Ag atoms fall in the range varying from 2.7711(18) to 3.420(3) Å, which are shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of the Ag ion (3.44 Å), indicating significant argentophilic interactions. Then, the rich Ag···Ag interactions aggregate adjacent Ag atoms into two independent 1D chains containing symmetry-related Ag1 and Ag2 (b). Two crystallographically equivalent AgI atoms are clamped by two pairs of carboxyl groups to form the [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBU with a Ag1···Ag1i contact of 2.7711(18) Å, which is even 0.11 Å shorter than the Ag···Ag contact in bulk Ag (2.89 Å). [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBUs were extended by (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 bdc2– and bidentate pz ligands to a complicated 3D network (c,d). According to TOPOS analysis, as depicted in e, the [Ag2(COO)2] units of 1@298 K can be seen as 4-connected nodes and the longer Ag1···Ag1ii contact of 2.980(2) Å was omitted; the topology of 1@298 K is an unusual 4-connected doubly interpenetrated lvt network (f) with a point symbol of {42·84}. For 1@298 K, two interpenetrated lvt networks are reinforced by Ag···Ag interactions and related to a 2-fold axis without any interpenetrating translations and thus can be classified as the type class IIa, where Z t = 1 and Z n = 2. The common 4-connected uninodal 3D networks are dia, qtz, sra, sod, nbo, cds, pts, and mog, but the lvt network is very rare in coordination compounds. Previously documented uncommon 4-connected networks are [Pb3Cl3(OH)­(succinate)] n , {[Cu­(4,4′-bipyridine)2(CF3SO3)2]·2CH2Cl2·2H2O} n , and {[Cu­(oxybisbenzoate)­(H2O)]2·0.5H2O} n , which exhibited zero, double, and quintuple interpenetration, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Ag2(pz)(bdc)⋅H2O] n  (1@298 K)

SCXRD analysis demonstrates that 1@298 K is a 3D class IIa, doubly interpenetrated lvt network. It crystallizes in the orthorhombic Ibca space group at 298 K. The asymmetric unit of 1@298 K consists of two crystallographically unique AgI atoms, one pz ligand, one bdc2- dianion, and one solvent water molecule. As depicted in a, the Ag1 atom locates in a T-shaped geometry, coordinated by two O atoms from two different bdc2- ligands and one N atom of the pz ligand [Ag1-O1 = 2.172(4) Å, Ag1-O2i = 2.193(3) Å, and Ag1-N1 = 2.365(4) Å; ∠O1-Ag1-O2i = 164.25(14)°]. Differently, Ag2 is in a three-coordinated Y-shaped geometry comprised of two O atoms of different bdc2- ligands and one N atom belonging to the pz ligand [Ag2-O4 = 2.296(4) Å, Ag2-O3iii = 2.245(4) Å, and Ag2-N2iv = 2.302(4) Å; ∠O3-Ag2-O4 = 139.16(15)°]. Both the Ag-O and Ag-N bond lengths fall in the normal ranges observed in related complexes. Notably, the separations between the Ag atoms fall in the range varying from 2.7711(18) to 3.420(3) Å, which are shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of the Ag ion (3.44 Å), indicating significant argentophilic interactions. Then, the rich Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions aggregate adjacent Ag atoms into two independent 1D chains containing symmetry-related Ag1 and Ag2 (b). Two crystallographically equivalent AgI atoms are clamped by two pairs of carboxyl groups to form the [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBU with a Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1i contact of 2.7711(18) Å, which is even 0.11 Å shorter than the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contact in bulk Ag (2.89 Å). [Ag2(COO)2] dimeric SBUs were extended by (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 bdc2- and bidentate pz ligands to a complicated 3D network (c,d). According to TOPOS analysis, as depicted in e, the [Ag2(COO)2] units of 1@298 K can be seen as 4-connected nodes and the longer Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1ii contact of 2.980(2) Å was omitted; the topology of 1@298 K is an unusual 4-connected doubly interpenetrated lvt network (f) with a point symbol of {42⋅84}. For 1@298 K, two interpenetrated lvt networks are reinforced by Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions and related to a 2-fold axis without any interpenetrating translations and thus can be classified as the type class IIa, where Z t = 1 and Z n = 2. The common 4-connected uninodal 3D networks are dia, qtz, sra, sod, nbo, cds, pts, and mog, but the lvt network is very rare in coordination compounds. Previously documented uncommon 4-connected networks are [Pb3Cl3(OH)(succinate)] n , {[Cu(4,4'-bipyridine)2(CF3SO3)2]⋅2CH2Cl2⋅2H2O} n , and {[Cu(oxybisbenzoate)(H2O)]2⋅0.5H2O} n , which exhibited zero, double, and quintuple interpenetration, respectively.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP representation of 1@298 K with the coordination environments around the AgI center with 50% thermal ellipsoid probability. Symmetry codes: (i) −x + 1/2, −y + 3/2, −z + 1/2; (ii) −x, −y + 3/2, z; (iii) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1; (iv) −x + 1/2, y – 1/2, z; (v) −x + 1/2, y + 1/2, z. (b) Independent 1D chains comprised of Ag1 or Ag2. (c) Single 3D network of 1@298 K. (d) Doubly interpenetrated 3D networks (networks individually colored). (e) 4-connected [Ag2(COO)2] node. (f) Simplified 3D 2-fold-interpenetrated lvt network.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP representation of 1@298 K with the coordination environments around the AgI center with 50% thermal ellipsoid probability. Symmetry codes: (i) -x + 1/2, -y + 3/2, -z + 1/2; (ii) -x, -y + 3/2, z; (iii) -x + 1, -y + 1, -z + 1; (iv) -x + 1/2, y - 1/2, z; (v) -x + 1/2, y + 1/2, z. (b) Independent 1D chains comprised of Ag1 or Ag2. (c) Single 3D network of 1@298 K. (d) Doubly interpenetrated 3D networks (networks individually colored). (e) 4-connected [Ag2(COO)2] node. (f) Simplified 3D 2-fold-interpenetrated lvt network.

elements.content: Interestingly, there are hydrophilic 1D channels running along the a axis (a). The coordination unsaturated carboxylate O atoms are exposed in the channel, forming the potential hydrogen-bond acceptors. The lattice water (symmetry-related O1) molecules are found to propagate along the crystallographic 21-screw axis in a helical fashion. For each water molecule, one hydrogen atom (donor) and one lone pair of electrons (acceptors) are involved in the construction of the 1D helix [2.804(10) and 2.805(9) Å; Table S3], which is anchored with the host through O1W···O3 hydrogen bonds [2.904(6) Å]. These hydrogen bonds are slightly longer than the 2.74 Å in ice I c and 2.76 Å in ice I h. The helically distributed carboxylate O atoms in the host give a 1D hydrophilic channel with inherent helicity, which as a template induces formation of the helical water chain (b,c). The left- and right-hand water chains are alternately arranged in the channels.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, there are hydrophilic 1D channels running along the a axis (a). The coordination unsaturated carboxylate O atoms are exposed in the channel, forming the potential hydrogen-bond acceptors. The lattice water (symmetry-related O1) molecules are found to propagate along the crystallographic 21-screw axis in a helical fashion. For each water molecule, one hydrogen atom (donor) and one lone pair of electrons (acceptors) are involved in the construction of the 1D helix [2.804(10) and 2.805(9) Å; Table S3], which is anchored with the host through O1W⋅⋅⋅O3 hydrogen bonds [2.904(6) Å]. These hydrogen bonds are slightly longer than the 2.74 Å in ice I c and 2.76 Å in ice I h. The helically distributed carboxylate O atoms in the host give a 1D hydrophilic channel with inherent helicity, which as a template induces formation of the helical water chain (b,c). The left- and right-hand water chains are alternately arranged in the channels.

elements.content: (a) 1D helical water chain shown in ball-and-stick mode. (b and c) 1D water chain hydrogen-bonded to a host network (green dashed line, hydrogen bonds within the chain; black dashed lines, hydrogen bonds formed between the 1D water chain and host network).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 1D helical water chain shown in ball-and-stick mode. (b and c) 1D water chain hydrogen-bonded to a host network (green dashed line, hydrogen bonds within the chain; black dashed lines, hydrogen bonds formed between the 1D water chain and host network).

elements.content: On cooling, the single crystal undergoes a phase transition at 147 K accompanied by a doubling of the crystallographic a axis and a change from the I to P lattice. The transition process was followed successfully using a CCD diffractometer, by indexing the cell unit parameter with a cooling speed of 1 K steps. The above change is not severe enough to lead to crystal breakage, and as a result, the study on both phases by SCXRD is feasible. It was also observed that interconversion between two phases is completely reversible at around 147 K. After phase transition, we found that the overall connectivity of the network is maintained and still belongs to a 2-fold interpenetrated lvt topology. However, the important structure change before and after phase transition is the coordination mode of bdc2–. Only (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 bdc2– was observed in 1@298 K, whereas both (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 and (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ2)-μ4 bdc2– were observed in 1@133 K (a,b), and as a result, the 4-connected [Ag2(COO)2] node is also different before and after phase transition (c,d). A similar phenomenon was also observed in several other SCSC examples. At first glance, most of the coordination bond distances and angles of 1@298 K closely resemble those in 1@133 K. Then we especially focus on the changes in the Ag···Ag interaction depending on the temperature. In 1, Ag···Ag interactions could be classified as two kinds, carboxylate-supported and ligand-unsupported. As shown in Table S4, most of the Ag···Ag bonds maintain a constant distance (varied within ca. 0.02 Å) except for one ligand-unsupported Ag2···Ag2iii, dramatically varying from 3.420(3) Å at 298 K to 3.2751(16) Å at 148 K with a magnitude of nearly 0.15 Å, indicating the high sensitivity of the ligand-unsupported Ag···Ag interaction to temperature (e). The occurrence of phase transition was also supported by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement. Two anomalies are found at 151 and 147 K during the heating–cooling cycle, which demonstrates that 1 undergoes a phase transition with a minor thermal hysteresis (f). The synergetic effect of varied coordinative and supramolecular interactions along with cooling cause the atom-position displacements, affecting their integral arrangement in the solid state; thus, some crystallographic symmetry elements were lost or added, resulting in the observed thermal-induced space-group transition.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal (SCSC) Phase Transition of 1 from Ibca to Pccn at ca. 147 K

On cooling, the single crystal undergoes a phase transition at 147 K accompanied by a doubling of the crystallographic a axis and a change from the I to P lattice. The transition process was followed successfully using a CCD diffractometer, by indexing the cell unit parameter with a cooling speed of 1 K steps. The above change is not severe enough to lead to crystal breakage, and as a result, the study on both phases by SCXRD is feasible. It was also observed that interconversion between two phases is completely reversible at around 147 K. After phase transition, we found that the overall connectivity of the network is maintained and still belongs to a 2-fold interpenetrated lvt topology. However, the important structure change before and after phase transition is the coordination mode of bdc2-. Only (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 bdc2- was observed in 1@298 K, whereas both (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ1)-μ4 and (κ1-κ1-κ1-κ2)-μ4 bdc2- were observed in 1@133 K (a,b), and as a result, the 4-connected [Ag2(COO)2] node is also different before and after phase transition (c,d). A similar phenomenon was also observed in several other SCSC examples. At first glance, most of the coordination bond distances and angles of 1@298 K closely resemble those in 1@133 K. Then we especially focus on the changes in the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction depending on the temperature. In 1, Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions could be classified as two kinds, carboxylate-supported and ligand-unsupported. As shown in Table S4, most of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag bonds maintain a constant distance (varied within ca. 0.02 Å) except for one ligand-unsupported Ag2⋅⋅⋅Ag2iii, dramatically varying from 3.420(3) Å at 298 K to 3.2751(16) Å at 148 K with a magnitude of nearly 0.15 Å, indicating the high sensitivity of the ligand-unsupported Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction to temperature (e). The occurrence of phase transition was also supported by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement. Two anomalies are found at 151 and 147 K during the heating-cooling cycle, which demonstrates that 1 undergoes a phase transition with a minor thermal hysteresis (f). The synergetic effect of varied coordinative and supramolecular interactions along with cooling cause the atom-position displacements, affecting their integral arrangement in the solid state; thus, some crystallographic symmetry elements were lost or added, resulting in the observed thermal-induced space-group transition.

elements.content: Coordination modes of bdc2– before (a) and after (b) phase transition shown in ball-and-stick mode. 1D helical water chain. The [Ag2(COO)2] SBU before (c) and after (d) phase transition. (e) Temperature-dependent Ag···Ag interaction before phase transition (purple dashed line, Ag···Ag interaction). (f) DSC curves of 1 obtained in a heating–cooling cycle.
elements.clean_text: 3  Coordination modes of bdc2- before (a) and after (b) phase transition shown in ball-and-stick mode. 1D helical water chain. The [Ag2(COO)2] SBU before (c) and after (d) phase transition. (e) Temperature-dependent Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction before phase transition (purple dashed line, Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction). (f) DSC curves of 1 obtained in a heating-cooling cycle.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent emissive behavior of complex 1 was investigated between 290 and 80 K to track its response to temperature (a). The luminescent decay of 1 showed monoexponential behavior with decay times on a microsecond scale (τ290 K = 9.21 and τ80 K = 24.45 μs; Figure S3), which indicates a spin-forbidden triplet parentage. The absolute luminescence quantum yield determined using an integrating sphere is 7.2% at 298 K. Overall, the luminescent intensity progressively increases, and the emission lifetimes were also elongated upon cooling. These behaviors should be correlated with the rigidity enhancement, and the heavy-atom effect induced a faster intersystem crossing process upon cooling, which effectively diminished the loss of energy in the nonradiation decay process. Interestingly, the emission peak shifting trends in different temperature regions were inverse. When the temperature decreased from 290 to 170 K, the emission band gradually red-shifted from 590 → 592 → 598 → 601 → 603 nm with a slight enhancement of the intensity. Then, emission bands blue-shifted from 592 to 585 nm and then to 583 nm accompanying a sharply increased intensity were observed upon further cooling from 170 to 80 K (b). These emissions of 1 at different temperatures could be tentatively assigned as a triplet metal-to-ligand charge-transfer [Ag → π*­(pz)] excited state and mixed with the Ag···Ag [4d → 5s] triplet-cluster-centered (3CC) excited state.
elements.clean_text:
Thermochromic Luminescence of 1 

The temperature-dependent emissive behavior of complex 1 was investigated between 290 and 80 K to track its response to temperature (a). The luminescent decay of 1 showed monoexponential behavior with decay times on a microsecond scale (τ290 K = 9.21 and τ80 K = 24.45 μs; Figure S3), which indicates a spin-forbidden triplet parentage. The absolute luminescence quantum yield determined using an integrating sphere is 7.2% at 298 K. Overall, the luminescent intensity progressively increases, and the emission lifetimes were also elongated upon cooling. These behaviors should be correlated with the rigidity enhancement, and the heavy-atom effect induced a faster intersystem crossing process upon cooling, which effectively diminished the loss of energy in the nonradiation decay process. Interestingly, the emission peak shifting trends in different temperature regions were inverse. When the temperature decreased from 290 to 170 K, the emission band gradually red-shifted from 590 → 592 → 598 → 601 → 603 nm with a slight enhancement of the intensity. Then, emission bands blue-shifted from 592 to 585 nm and then to 583 nm accompanying a sharply increased intensity were observed upon further cooling from 170 to 80 K (b). These emissions of 1 at different temperatures could be tentatively assigned as a triplet metal-to-ligand charge-transfer [Ag → π*(pz)] excited state and mixed with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag [4d → 5s] triplet-cluster-centered (3CC) excited state.

elements.content: (a) Luminescence spectra of 1 from 290 to 80 K in the solid state under 365 nm excitation. (b) Plots of the maximum emission wavelength versus luminescence intensity of 1 under 365 nm excitation at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Luminescence spectra of 1 from 290 to 80 K in the solid state under 365 nm excitation. (b) Plots of the maximum emission wavelength versus luminescence intensity of 1 under 365 nm excitation at different temperatures.

elements.content: To elucidate the correlations between the luminescence thermochromism and crystalline molecular structures, we performed variable-temperature SCXRD (VT-SCXRD) on an individual crystal at 298, 263, 213, 163, 148, 133, 113, and 93 K (Table S1), which showed a close correlation of the structural parameters of 1 versus its luminescence behavior as a function of the temperature. Table S4 lists the X-ray-determined Ag···Ag contacts in 1 at eight temperatures. To the best of our knowledge, the Ag···Ag interactions usually influence the energy level related to the 3CC state. Upon cooling from 298 to 148 K, contraction of the Ag···Ag contacts increased the bonding character and thus decreased the energy level of the 3CC transition state, which shifted the emission band to lower energy (longer wavelength). As the temperature was further decreased, especially lower than 147 K, phase transition occurred. Thereafter, most of the Ag···Ag distances continued to be shortened, but the shrinkage degree remained at the 10–2 Å magnitude, whereas the influence of rigid enhancement on luminescence became more popular; that is to say, in the competitive influence of argentophilic interactions and rigidity of the structure, the latter is obviously dominated at lower temperatures, which combined with the structural phase transition caused the emission bands at 140–80 K to blue shift.
elements.clean_text: To elucidate the correlations between the luminescence thermochromism and crystalline molecular structures, we performed variable-temperature SCXRD (VT-SCXRD) on an individual crystal at 298, 263, 213, 163, 148, 133, 113, and 93 K (Table S1), which showed a close correlation of the structural parameters of 1 versus its luminescence behavior as a function of the temperature. Table S4 lists the X-ray-determined Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts in 1 at eight temperatures. To the best of our knowledge, the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions usually influence the energy level related to the 3CC state. Upon cooling from 298 to 148 K, contraction of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts increased the bonding character and thus decreased the energy level of the 3CC transition state, which shifted the emission band to lower energy (longer wavelength). As the temperature was further decreased, especially lower than 147 K, phase transition occurred. Thereafter, most of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances continued to be shortened, but the shrinkage degree remained at the 10-2 Å magnitude, whereas the influence of rigid enhancement on luminescence became more popular; that is to say, in the competitive influence of argentophilic interactions and rigidity of the structure, the latter is obviously dominated at lower temperatures, which combined with the structural phase transition caused the emission bands at 140-80 K to blue shift.

elements.content: So far, the thermochromic luminescence has been widely found in polynuclear CuI, AgI, and AuI coordination compounds and has a close relationship with variation of the metallophilicity within the clusters. The luminescence chromism in response to temperature change always shows single change trends, intensity enhancement, and red or blue shifts; however, mixed red- and blue-shifted luminescence thermochromism in one complex has not been observed.
elements.clean_text: So far, the thermochromic luminescence has been widely found in polynuclear CuI, AgI, and AuI coordination compounds and has a close relationship with variation of the metallophilicity within the clusters. The luminescence chromism in response to temperature change always shows single change trends, intensity enhancement, and red or blue shifts; however, mixed red- and blue-shifted luminescence thermochromism in one complex has not been observed.

elements.content: Besides the temperature, the emission color of 1 can also be changed by mechanical force. When a colorless crystalline sample was strongly ground in an agate mortar with a pestle, the color of 1 under ambient light remained unchanged, whereas the luminescence changed from luminous yellow to pale yellow under irradiation by a UV lamp (a). As shown in b, the unground sample displayed a luminescent peak at 589 nm, which red-shifted to 604 nm after grinding. Variable-temperature luminescence of the ground sample showed very similar luminescence thermochromism behavior with respect to the unground sample (Figure S4), but the maximum emission peaks at the same temperature show a red-shift phenomenon (c). The emission lifetimes and quantum yields of 1 after grinding are 2.30 μs and 5.3%, respectively, which are identical with those of unground 1 within the margin of error. Microscopic analyses for 1 before and after grinding indicate that no chemical components were incorporated or excluded during the grinding process. The IR spectra () and compared PXRD patterns (Figure S6) for 1 before and after grinding also rule out the occurrence of possible chemical reactions and network collapse, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanochromic Luminescence of 1 

Besides the temperature, the emission color of 1 can also be changed by mechanical force. When a colorless crystalline sample was strongly ground in an agate mortar with a pestle, the color of 1 under ambient light remained unchanged, whereas the luminescence changed from luminous yellow to pale yellow under irradiation by a UV lamp (a). As shown in b, the unground sample displayed a luminescent peak at 589 nm, which red-shifted to 604 nm after grinding. Variable-temperature luminescence of the ground sample showed very similar luminescence thermochromism behavior with respect to the unground sample (Figure S4), but the maximum emission peaks at the same temperature show a red-shift phenomenon (c). The emission lifetimes and quantum yields of 1 after grinding are 2.30 μs and 5.3%, respectively, which are identical with those of unground 1 within the margin of error. Microscopic analyses for 1 before and after grinding indicate that no chemical components were incorporated or excluded during the grinding process. The IR spectra () and compared PXRD patterns (Figure S6) for 1 before and after grinding also rule out the occurrence of possible chemical reactions and network collapse, respectively.

elements.content: (a) Photographs showing luminescence changes of 1 upon grinding at room temperature with a UV lamp (365 nm). (b) Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 before and after grinding at room temperature. (c) Comparison of the maximum emission wavelengths of unground and ground 1 versus temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Photographs showing luminescence changes of 1 upon grinding at room temperature with a UV lamp (365 nm). (b) Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 before and after grinding at room temperature. (c) Comparison of the maximum emission wavelengths of unground and ground 1 versus temperatures.

elements.content: In conclusion, a stimuli-responsive 3D AgI-based coordination network was constructed by one-pot assembly and structurally characterized by VT-SCXRD. Its structure features an unusual 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected lvt network with [Ag2(COO)2] dimers as SBUs. 1 undergo an interesting SCSC phase transition from orthorhombic Ibca (Z = 16) to Pccn (Z = 32) at around 147 K by several structural variations such as the coordination mode of the ligand and supramolecular interactions. Notably, complex 1 shows unusual thermochromic luminescence behavior with a segmented shift phenomenon, that is, red- and blue-shifted in 298–147 and 147–80 K temperature ranges, respectively, which is assigned to not only the thermal-triggered variation of intramolecular Ag···Ag contacts but also the phase transitions. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits moderate mechanoluminescence red shifts from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a stimuli-responsive 3D AgI-based coordination network was constructed by one-pot assembly and structurally characterized by VT-SCXRD. Its structure features an unusual 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected lvt network with [Ag2(COO)2] dimers as SBUs. 1 undergo an interesting SCSC phase transition from orthorhombic Ibca (Z = 16) to Pccn (Z = 32) at around 147 K by several structural variations such as the coordination mode of the ligand and supramolecular interactions. Notably, complex 1 shows unusual thermochromic luminescence behavior with a segmented shift phenomenon, that is, red- and blue-shifted in 298-147 and 147-80 K temperature ranges, respectively, which is assigned to not only the thermal-triggered variation of intramolecular Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts but also the phase transitions. Upon being mechanically ground, 1 exhibits moderate mechanoluminescence red shifts from 589 to 604 nm at 298 K.

cln_elements.content: Solution assembly of Ag2O, pz, and H2bdc in 1:1 (v/v) water–methanol mixed with 400 μL of ammonia at room temperature yielded colorless, very long (up to several centimeters) rod crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 is supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is well-matched with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The dissimilarity in the intensity is possibly caused by the preferred orientation of the powder samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 is performed under a N2 environment (Figure S2). For 1, the first weight loss of 3.02% from 30 to 80 °C is attributed to the extraction of water molecules (calcd 3.77%); then a platform appears in 80–135 °C, and the dehydrated network decomposes from 135 °C by removal of the organic ligands. These results match well with structural information on 1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solution assembly of Ag2O, pz, and H2bdc in 1:1 (v/v) water-methanol mixed with 400 μL of ammonia at room temperature yielded colorless, very long (up to several centimeters) rod crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 is supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is well-matched with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The dissimilarity in the intensity is possibly caused by the preferred orientation of the powder samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 is performed under a N2 environment (Figure S2). For 1, the first weight loss of 3.02% from 30 to 80 °C is attributed to the extraction of water molecules (calcd 3.77%); then a platform appears in 80-135 °C, and the dehydrated network decomposes from 135 °C by removal of the organic ligands. These results match well with structural information on 1.

(f) Simplified 3D 2-fold-interpenetrated lvt network.

metadata.title:
Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Phase Transition and Segmented Thermochromic
Luminescence in a Dynamic 3D Interpenetrated AgI Coordination
Network
